bboxes.raw_text:
FLAGSTAFF DR.. Martin
Luther King, Negro civil rights
leader from Birmingham, Ala,
will appear here Feb. 7 on fund
raising campaign.


The Baptist minister will ap-
pear for the Southern Christian
Leadership Conference, which he
heads.


Rev. ]. R. Monsoon, pastor of
the Harbert AME Chapel in Flag
staff and president of the West
ern Christian Leadership Con-
ference, said the group will try
to obtain use of the Arizona State
College auditorium for King 8
appearance.
DR.. KING TO APPEAR

TAMPA, Fla = Funeral SER
vices we're held in Tampa last
week for woman known for her
joviality, her friendliness, and
her size.


Known to thousands, in and out
of show business, as baby
Helen" Tampa's famous fiat
Lady," Mrs. Helen Jones, 48,
died of a heart attack.


When she died, Mrs. Jones
weighed slightly more than 900
pounds. At the height of her ca
reer, when she performed as the
celebrated "Baby Helen." she
weighed 700 pounds. A fairly tall
woman, S feet 9 ~ inches,
her measurements we're o8-83-
1O2.

CIRCUS FAT WOMAN
DIES IN TAMPA

TUSCALOOSA, Ala. = A grand
fury indicted five Alabama Ma
tional Cuardsmen for setting off
a series of explosions near the
integrated University of alabama
campus last October.


Tuscaloosa County Circuit So
licitor Fred Ncol said trials
for the Cuardsmen, formally
charged with setting off dyna-
mite near an Inhabited dwelling"
could be held In March.


Under Alabama law, the crime
can be punished by death but
Nicol said he would not seek the
death penalty because no one was
injured by the blast.


The five Guardsmen we're al
lowed to remain free on the same
bonds they posted when they we're
arrested during December.


They were part of a special
detail on federalized duty to pro-
tect the campus from possible
violence because of desegrega-
ton.


One of the blasts occurred
within a block of the dormitory
where Vivian Malone, the
schools only Negro student, was
housed.


All of the blasts we're set
off in or near the streets. Prin-
cipal damage was to windows.


The Guardsmen are End 1t.
James Perkins Of Holt; lst Sgt.
Norman Daliel of Fairfield, and
Sgts. Charles Holifield Of Mari
on, James T. Maxwell of Tus-
caloosa and william Roughton Of
Langdale.


Police said at the time of ar
rests that 1t was believed the
blasts we're set off to keep ten
sions high and to keep the unit
federalized. Some of the Guards
men on federal service drew both
full-time Army and civilian pay
during their tour of duty.

GRAND JURY INDICTS
FIVE GUARDS
FOR EXPLOSIONS AT
u OF ALABAMA

PRESCOTT Prescott High
School will forfeit all athletic
events in which Flagstaff s James
Dugan is participant.


Supt. of Schools Abba w. Judd
said that the five-member Pres
colt School Board voted unani-
mously to take the action.


Judd said, however, Prescott
will maintain relations with Flag
staff High in all events where
Dugan does not compete.


This means the Jan. 81 bask-
etball game between the two high
schools is off. All baseball games
also will be forfeited as Dugan
is to be a member of the Flag
staff team.


Judd said full relations will be
resumed next year. Dugan grad
yates this spring.


The board acted as a result
of high feelings between the two
northern Arizona high schools
following a recent Prescott
Flagstaff basketball game.


In the final seconds Of the
game, Dugan slugged Prescott s
Randy Emmett.


The ls-year-old Emmett suf-
fered facial and head injuries.
He spent several days in the
Prescott hospital, then was sent
to a Phoenix hospital for facial
surgery.


Prescott filed a report with the
Arizona Interscholastic Associa-
ton and requested an investiga-
ton. The ALA has taken no &C.
ton, but the groups executive
board Is to meet in Phoenix
Jan. %.

PRESCOTT HALTS


FLAGSTAFF PLAYING

WASHINGTON = About the time
you get Christmas paid for, 1t
will be time for another annual
expense-automobile tags.


This Is an item that has been
going up generally, with more
and more cities and towns get
ting into the act along with the
states.


The top charges run as high
as $72.o5, in Oklahoma, and
S6o.35 in Minnesota.


A mass of information has
been gathered about car tags
by the American Automobile As
sociation and the National Geo.
graphic Society.


For one thing, there seems to
be a trend toward making the
tags good for more than one
year. Nineteen states now issue
stickers or tabs instead of re-
quiring an annual replacement
of plates.


The average cost of manufac-
turing tags runs about is to 80
cents. Nearly all are made by
prison labor. The size Is now
a standard IL by 6 inches, after
many years Of variety.

AUTO TAGS


COSTS RISING

The UL label on a product is a
sign of safety. But in addition, it
offers assurance of adequate per-
Torrance.


For example, those asphalt
shingles that are approved for
wind-resistance by Underwriters
Laboratories have met strict
standards for materials and have
passed severe wind.tunnel tests.

VI Label Signifies


Safety, Performance

@. How much insulation should
Ihave installed in my new house?
It's going to be centrally air.
conditioned.


A. Follow the recommends.
tons Of the National Mineral
Wool Insulation Association,
which puts out an air condition.
ing calculator for builders and
air conditioning contractors. The
calculator quickly shows them
how much insulation is needed
for maximum comfort and mini
mum air-conditioning costs.


@. How can I be sure of get
ting fire-resistant roofing?


A. The Pacific Fire Rating
Bureau has approved several
roofing materials for fire resist
ance. These include metal, tile,
slate or composition, such as as
phalt shingles, and built-up
asphalt and rock roofing. Specify
one of these.


@. We need a few trees for
shade and privacy. Can you rec
ommend a fast-growing variety?


A. Check with your local nur-
seryman about the California
Alder (Alnus rhombifolia). The
foliage is very dense, and growth
is rapid-14 to Is feet in two
years after planting is not un-
usual. In time, these trees will
grow from 40 to 80 feet high.

PATRONIZE YOUR
ADVERTISERS

QUESTION:

HOLLYWOOD = Sammy Davis,
Jr., Frank Sinatra, Dean Mar
tin, Nelson Riddle S orchestra,
and other stars in the enter
tainment field raised $4,000 for
the support of civil rights orga-
nizations at their recent Santa
Monica Civic Auditorium Show.

$40, 600 RAISED FOR
RIGHTS GROUPS

Z 1uOuSCT1eS Association
has taken a look into what
chronological developments this
nation may expect within the
next decade and it's forecast
will make space data today as
passe as the jet has overshad-
owed the Wright brothers first
flight over Kitty Hawk, NC,
in 1908.


The focal point Of this huge
chronological fort is the de-
velopment Of vehicles and sup
port equipment that can carry
man to the moon and back. At
the same time, the aerospace
industry IL developing very
high-performance aircraft, and
liRh.speed Vertical Takeoff and
Landing Craft, with great-vers-
ability, which will become oper-
ational before 1912.


Though ALA makes no at
tempt to predict major break
throughs in technology, 1t points
out that the general trends and
requirements for the space pro-
gram over the next 10 years
"can be forecast with reason
able certainty" And among the
general trends an q require.
Ynents its forecasts are:


y Newly-developed COMPUTE
ers to take over the role Of
countdown procedures for space
flight, which for the most part
are now dependent on manual
operations.


~ The memory capacity Of
ground-based data processing
equipment that will increase
about 1000, 900 times over the
present units.


81 The temperature resist
ance Of metal alloys will In
crease about 1000 degrees
Tahrenheit-a factor that has
slowed the development Of high
performance aerospace vehicles.


These aspects Of future space
flights are incorporated In a
new publication, The Aerospace
Technical Forecast, which was
prepared by the Aerospace In
dustries Association. The publ
cation IL a guide to industry en-
gineers as well as subcontrac-
tors a n d suppliers for future
planning. Copies Of the report
are $500 each and are avail
able at Aerospace Industries
Association, 1925 DeSales st.
NV, Washington 6, DC.


Trends and Requirements


The publication divides the
trends and requirements" into
eight sections: environmenlal,
system, propulsion, materials,
system components, groun d
support equipment, manufacture
ing process and testing.


AS for the systems, the Fore
cast notes there will be a re-
quirement for ct least 10 times
90 many major training sys.
TENS. Training simulators,
which duplicate on the ground
the stresses and conditions IN
flight will become more import
ant. It predicts an improve
ment in reliability Of electronic
systems as much as 100 times
greater than today.


Forecast also predicts that
DEVELOPMENT will start tn the
next decade on a single-chamb-
er rocket engine producing 6 to
8 million pounds Of thrust. This
means that by clustering these
engines, booster power In the
range Of Is to go million pounds
Of first stage thrust can be
produced. This compares with
the current Atlas booster Of
more than $4,000 pounds.


Tensile Strength


Lack of proper materials has
been q major difficulty in the
development Of most high-per-
Torrance aerospace vehicles. In
addition to inceasing the temp
erature resistance of refractory
metal alloys by as much as
1000 degrees Fahrenheit, the
tensile strength of glass fiber
reinforced plastics is expected
to rise from 100000 pounds per
square inch to 100000 during
the next ten years. This means
10 YEARS FROM NOW
WASHINGTON

ping family the fresh flavor OF the enriched corn
meal on top of a delicious stew.
